name: General Knowledge 16 Quiz | Mixed 25 Questions | 25 Questions

questions.text: Name the foolish king in classical mythology who asked that everything he touched should turn to gold?
questions.explanation:
Midas.

	As a reward for rendering a service to a god he asked that everything he touched should become gold. He found he was unable to eat or drink because his food was also transformed. The story was told by Roman poet Ovid.

questions.text: In which book would you find 'Pushmi - Pullyu'?
questions.explanation:
Doctor Doolittle.

	A two-headed animal.

questions.text: The novel 'Les Miserables' was written by _________?
questions.explanation:
Victor Hugo.

	The central character was Jean Valjean who was sent to prison for stealing bread.

questions.text: Who lives at 4 Privet Drive, Little Whinging, Surrey with uncle Vernon and aunt Petunia?
questions.explanation: Harry Potter.

questions.text: How many bones are there in total in the two human ears?
questions.explanation:
6.

	The malleus (hammer), incus (anvil) and stapes (stirrup) in each ear.

questions.text: What is the name of the gamekeeper in the novel 'Lady Chatterley's Lover' by D.H. Lawrence. Oliver _______?
questions.explanation: Mellors.

questions.text: Which of the following film titles is a 'Marx Brothers' film?
questions.explanation:
Duck Soup.

	Duck Soup (1933). Horse Feathers (1932).

questions.text: Name the architect who designed the 'Queen's House' at Greenwich (1616) and the 'Banqueting House' in Westminster (1619-22) _____ Jones?
questions.explanation: Inigo.

questions.text: The 'Zulu Wars' occurred in which country?
questions.explanation:
South Africa.

	The Zulus of South Africa clashed with white settlers called Boers in 1836. In 1879 British troops finally defeated the Zulu army ending Zulu resistance to European rule.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a bird name?
questions.explanation:
Curfew.

	A curlew is a large shore bird. A curfew is an official regulation setting restrictions on movement especially after a specific time at night. Another name for the cormorant is the shag and the goatsucker is the American and Canadian name for the nightjar.

questions.text: Complete the famous artist's name: Jacques Louis _______?
questions.explanation:
David.

	David painted 'Death of Marat'. Jean-Paul Marat was a leader of the French Revolution of 1789 and a personal friend of David. Marat became a martyr to the cause when he was stabbed to death in his bath by Charlotte Corday, a fervent royalist.

questions.text: In which country would you find the port of Fray Bentos associated with meat processing of corned beef?
questions.explanation: Uruguay.

questions.text: Name Tom Sawyer's sweetheart in the book 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer'?
questions.explanation: Becky Thatcher.

questions.text: In which country does the international airport 'Vitoria' serve?
questions.explanation: Spain.

questions.text: What is the name of the captain in 'The Adventures of Tintin'?
questions.explanation:
Haddock.

	Other characters include: Professor Calculus, pet pooch Snowy and bumbling policemen Thompson and Thomson.

questions.text: Who wrote the book 'The Prince and the Pauper'?
questions.explanation: Mark Twain.

questions.text: Who was the first European to reach the southern tip of Africa?
questions.explanation:
Bartolomeu Diaz.

	This Portuguese navigator was the first European to round the Cape of Good Hope in 1487 which opened the long sought route to India.

questions.text: Which plant does not belong to the same family group as all of the others?
questions.explanation:
Coffee.

	All these plants belong to the group 'nightshade' apart from coffee which belongs to the group 'madder'.

questions.text: Who was the author of the book 'The Bonfire of the Vanities'?
questions.explanation: Tom Wolfe.

questions.text: The tune 'Also Sprach Zarathustra' by Richard Strauss was associated with which of the following films?
options: Close Encounters of the Third Kind (1977)
questions.explanation:
2001: A Space Odyssey (1968).

	'Thus spoke Zarathustra'. The music represents the wise man Zarathustra as he descends from a mountain to preach his gospel to the people.

questions.text: Who is the film director of 'Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone'?
questions.explanation:
Chris Columbus.

	Apart from the 2.5 hour length of the film, the directing was plain sailing.

questions.text: Upon which river does Dallas in Texas stand?
questions.explanation: Trinity.

questions.text: Which major island group of the following consists of the most islands?
questions.explanation:
Philippines.

	Philippines = 7100, Japan = 1000 + , Fiji = 844, and Scilly Isles = 140.

questions.text: What was the name of the only painting Vincent Van Gogh sold during his lifetime for 400 francs?
questions.explanation:
The Red Vineyard.

	It is now in the Pushkin museum in Moscow.

questions.text: The French Revolution began in the same year as which of the following world events?
options: The opening of the Suez Canal
questions.explanation:
The Mutiny on the Bounty.

	1789 was the year the French Revolution began and the Mutiny on the Bounty occurred. In 1804, Napoleon was made Emperor. In 1840 the bicycle was invented in Scotland and 1869 was the year the Suez Canal was opened. Hope you enjoyed the quiz.
